titleStmt.title: M1-8, 7 of 10. [If you have read this brittle & imperfect sketch...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 27-32. 6p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8-7. [If you have read this brittle & imperfect sketch...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 27-32. 6p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.s: It is time that another attitude
Suppose that for a moment we cease to concern ourselves with the sequence in time, there is another way of looking at these famous monuments.

div.p: The critic, we must admit, is a one of the least real of writers, the most inhibited the most restricted. of writers On the one hand Suppose he attempts to convey his own impression – so often his emotion runs counter to his reason. The pressure
This [naked?] & imperfect sketch leaves requires to be

p.s: You will complain that this rushed & imperfect sketch has shown you nothing of the real force behind this th these famous monuments. Let us for a moment then look at them from a different angle. It is a charge that can be levelled against all out criticism. For though the reader who For the critic has No sooner has the pen touched the page, than there rise up so many of those influences which are hostile to the transmission of the emotion.

div.p: You will say that there is no inducement is given you to believe that the in the

p.s: For a moment let us change the angle. Let us discuss the difficulties of criticism. In the first place one of the greatest is that we cannot explain the instinct that the critic is mere art of criticism the erection of a all outing is alluded with great drawbacks. It is perpetually interrupted. It is overshadowed. It is impossible to

div.p: Let us then attempt what for one brief moment that very dangerous transition: from one attitude of mind to another. In this case from the omniscient to the fallible. It is & admit in the first place, that the scene we cannot say have the creative impulse, save by giving experience to it ourselves. Thus the time Therefore when we talk of the plays of And as anybody knows who has written even a short story the creative impulse is only to be stated in its own terms. If then we want to convey any notion So Talk It is undeniable that the creation of a work of art by some one else produces something an emotion in us. And the origin of [illeg.] is the desire to in in the first place [illeg.] to transmit this emotion & then to explain it. The difficulties that make this an impossible undertaking. Take, as a simple instance, the quotation This In order to copy out even one stage of a play, it is necessary to open at the right page then to copy accurately. This at once breaks the stream of thought. Besides, there is always present the other critic – Let us see him in person – a For ever

so many years, he has not been later than nine at the [illeg.]. Or, his lectures have been so regular that one cd (could) find hum at his place at the reading desk at ni [lunch?] every Monday. He st There is no need to discuss the effect of that prohibition. If we could evade all this, we should ahve to seek into a very dirty layer of the mind. to be able to put down the book & the paper & the pen. to dis free ourselves entirely from the subservience to the fact to free ourselves from all the [impositions?] of authority & the dominion of what is customary. How often to say openly that there is nothing doing. There is to slip into all these are done force that diminish, distort the fact is tha It is would be

Let us say then that try then to recapture some actual experience, which seems to have a connection, though a different one, with the experience of reading these old books: to spring from poetry; to be [interfaced?] with the same emotion. Let us forget For exam

If [illeg.] If still ran, let us take it when the [owling?] time is at hand, down to . There is a curious smell in this part of the world, of hops, [illeg.]; & also a curious [illeg.] a woman from one way hails a man from the other. The shouted words imply Here there is no differentiation. The streets are drab enough. The river has a great turbulent swollen stream. The cranes are picking sacks from the holds of ships. There is a

shiny slab of mud beneath the warehouses; & rises. The gulls are swooping; & some small boys paddle in the pebbles. Above the sky is huddled & crowded with purple streamers. We are still thinking of the plays, because it was here that the stood. Now let us give way to the imagination. After all what are four hundred years. We can What The roar & the chaos; the [friend?] of which; the general diffusion: all soon breed a great device for statement. Such was one of the elements in the drama. Another, the language. In Here is the unwritten poem. In this disorder, this sound, the difficulty of keeping away from the statement. A roar, a general incoherence. the presence of light, & [sentences?]; some saying: an attitude. In us leaving over the river, long one way in some alley; there rises the curious nameless drive to express – but less
The more heightened the more need of poetry Who is there
If It is equally important, to the understanding of the poem, to not to read at all. to dip, now & again into the inchoate & to talk, with many [illeg.], much felt art.

p.s: This is particularly true today; when the [economic?] force is cutting the critic into a special force.

div.p: For then we revive the reader – a very impatient person. The For the reader was born when the playhouse closed.

This brittle & imperfect sketch, with its exaggerations & foreshortenings, serves to bring out only the shapes of certain prominent objects; but & To convey The & that perhaps so partially that they are unrecognisable. Its implications can [illeg.] pointed out by removing for a moment, the critical attitude; & talking for a moment as Let us talk for a moment without the book. Let us look at the critical position & discover why it is so alien to the private position. In the first place the critic is infallible. But in order to adress this attitude he has to stiffen himself a more supple method [illeg.] needed. If we could return to the age of innocence: if we could talk, if we could even write a letter to a friend about . Indeed the som deplore some way of preserving those natural exclamations.

Much It is a long time our ; our the London of books; their the we frequency with which they [dumb?] [hunger?]: if we could return to the innocent state of [memory?]: as given & also those [desiring?] cries But wecome, at the end; when so much has been said so much said so much known: so great a human effort has been expended. In order to provide us with our knowledge, many lives have been passed in coal mines: And tho the result is often of no importance, we must repeat the effort. A great [anti?] room separates us from the book, filled with [loved? bored?], yet [illeg.] readers. Often we a
